title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Soonwe came to corn-fields in the valley ; passed Savanche and Lnchmore, and got on to a good road,on which Brown and Grant " traveled" at a wonderful pace, upward of five miles an hour vdthout stopping ; and the former with that vigorouslight, elastic tread which is quite astonishing,We passed DaPna-Damph Shiel (a shooting-lodgeof Sir Charles Forbes), and went along the old"Military Road," leaving Cockbridge, a small straggling " toun," which is on the road to Lnverness,to our left, and the old Castle of Corgarf to ourH

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We got off and walked a good long wayon the top of the very steep hills overhanging theloch, to the Stron, and the Moss of Mon Elpie,whence you overlook all the country belongingto Lord Panmure, Mount Keen, the OgilvieHills, &c. We stopped to rest' a little while —though the walking is excellent, so hard and dry— on a point overlooking the Shiel of the Glassalt,and the head of the loch.

title: Forty years on the stage :

snippet: Rose Massey was splendid as Claire Folliott, Beveridge excellent as Corry Kinchclls, Nerney made a " hit " in Shiel Barry's part of Harvey Duff, and Miss Rayne was a deliciously piquant and pretty Moya.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: He then proceeded to comment on the speech of Mr. Shiel,and then opening out on more extended topics,took the following high tone, and entered intothat general manifestation of principle, as heldby himself and his coadjutors, wdiich I extracthere, and of which I may observe, that it wasreceived with a constant succession of vehementcheers and enthusiastic applause.

snippet: preached the funeral sermon of his venerable parishioner, Tibbie Shiel.1 If the evening on which thisannual service was held turned out stormy or disagreeable, the congregation assembled in the FreeChurch at Cappercleugh.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: In 1875 Tibbie Shiel toldthe writer that she had heard him preach in Ettrick Churchand mentioned his subject, "Naomi," with certain particulars ofthe discourse, adding that it produced a great impression on thecongregation.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: Associated with these eminent persons, mentionmust be made of a Yarrow parishioner of humblerorigin, but whose name is known far and wide—Tibbie Shiel.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: Tibbie Shiel, already mentioned, survived, withher faculties wonderfully entire, till ninety-five years,at her little hostelry at the head of St Mary's Loch.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: There was Barbara Shiel, the housekeeper, whosemoney allowance could not be much less; therewas the annual payment to the Widows' Fund;there was the keep of a horse.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: 1 [Mrs Richardson (Tibbie Shiel) died in July 1S78, in herninety-sixth year. She was born near Ettrick church : in 1813,after her marriage, she removed to an old-fashioned cottage atthe upper end of the Loch of the Lowes, near Chapelhope ; andthence, in May 1823, shortly before the death of her husband, tothe well-known abode which bears her name, and in which shedied.—A.C.F.]

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: My nonagenarian parishioner and excellent friend"Tibbie Shiel"1 well remembered his coming toEttrick, and the impression made on the people byhis personnel and long fair hair, flowing in curls overhis shoulders, after the fashion of the day.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Mr. O'Connel and Mr.Shiel, may push the claims of Ireland too far and toofast, perhaps ; and they may be actuated by sinistermotives ; but they certainly have a right to cry out,against the oppression which has so long trodden herin the dust.
